instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3208: What is 820-3208? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: [SOLVED]SMC Compatibility
threads.message:
Hi team,

I wanted to know if some one could tell / explain me if the following SMC references are compatible as they're programmed: [h=3]LM4FS1BH5BBCIGR
LM4FSXAH5BB
LM4FS1AH5BBCIG
LM4FS1BH5BBCIG
LM4FS1GH5BBFIG
LM4FS1EH5BBCICG[/h] In my case i'm looking for the LM4FSXAH5BB for a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board. and just found the other references on aliexpress.
Or my only chance to replace it is to get it from a donor board?

threads.title: [SOLVED]SMC Compatibility
threads.message: Just buy a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> donor board and take the SMC from there, SMC has firmware and it should be exactly the same, also you will have a donor board for future repairs...

threads.title: [SOLVED]SMC Compatibility
threads.message:
Be aware that LM4FS* refers to the microprocessor and not to the actual programming flashed to it.

The longer number most likely refers to version, batch or specification. There is no 100% solid way to know what firmware its running

threads.title: [SOLVED]SMC Compatibility
threads.message: You must ALWAYS take and reball a donor SMC from an identical board.

threads.title: [SOLVED]SMC Compatibility
threads.message: Thanks guyz for these clear explainations.
